facts.text: This is an appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature for the State of Rajasthan under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution against its judgment confirming the Munsif-Magistrate's acquittal of the appellant under s. 353 IPC

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature for the State of Rajasthan, under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution against its judgment dated September 20, 1957, companyfirming that of the Munsif-Magistrate, Hinduan, acquitting the appellant of the charge under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated September 20, 1957 confirming Munsif-Magistrate Hinduan's order acquitting the appellant

anchor.surface_text: judgment dated September 20, 1957, companyfirming that of the Munsif-Magistrate, Hinduan, acquitting the appellant of the charge under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code. The material facts lie in a small companypass.

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent of Central Excise has head-quarters at Bharatpur

anchor.surface_text: The material facts lie in a small companypass. The Deputy Superintendent of the Central Excise, having his head-quarters at Bharatpur, received information that one Sulled and his son, Rehman, the respondent herein, had cultivated tobacco

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent received information that Sulled and his son Rehman had cultivated tobacco but had not paid excise duty

anchor.surface_text: Deputy Superintendent of the Central Excise, having his head-quarters at Bharatpur, received information that one Sulled and his son, Rehman, the respondent herein, had cultivated tobacco but had number paid the excise duty payable thereon.

facts.text: On September 9, 1953, Deputy Superintendent accompanied by Inspector of Central Excise, sepoy, chowkidar and two motbirs went to Rehman's house at 2 p.m. to search

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1953, the Deputy Superintendent, accompanied by an Inspector of Central Excise, a sepoy, a chowkidar and two motbirs went to the house of Rehman at 2 p.m., with a view to search his house to find out whether he had stored tobacco there.

facts.text: They declared intention to search Rehman's house

anchor.surface_text: When they declared their intention to do so, the respondent and one Dhamman, it is alleged, obstructed the making of the search with the result that the Deputy Superintendent fell down and received some injuries.

facts.text: Respondent Rehman and Dhamman allegedly obstructed the search causing Deputy Superintendent to fall and receive injuries

anchor.surface_text: the respondent and one Dhamman, it is alleged, obstructed the making of the search with the result that the Deputy Superintendent fell down and received some injuries. The respondent and Dhamman were prosecuted, and the Munsif-Magistrate, Hinduan, discharged Dhamman but companyvicted the respondent

facts.text: Respondent and Dhamman were prosecuted

anchor.surface_text: The respondent and Dhamman were prosecuted, and the Munsif-Magistrate, Hinduan, discharged Dhamman but companyvicted the respondent under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to undergo three months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Munsif-Magistrate Hinduan discharged Dhamman but convicted respondent under s. 353 IPC and sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: Munsif-Magistrate, Hinduan, discharged Dhamman but companyvicted the respondent under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to undergo three months rigorous imprisonment. On appeal, the Additional Sessions Judge came to the companyclusion

facts.text: On appeal, Additional Sessions Judge remanded the case because search not conducted in accordance with s. 165 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Additional Sessions Judge came to the companyclusion that on the material then available the search had number been companyducted in accordance with s. 165 of the Criminal Procedure Code and remanded the case for fresh enquiry.

facts.text: On remand, Munsif-Magistrate found search made without recording reasons under s. 165 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: On remand, the Munsif-Magistrate found that the search was made by the Deputy Superintendent without recording the reasons as he should under s. 165 of the Criminal Procedure Code and that the respondent in obstructing him from making the illegal search did number companymit any offence

facts.text: Munsif-Magistrate acquitted the respondent on finding search illegal

anchor.surface_text: and, on that finding, the acquitted the respondent. On appeal, the High Court agreed with the view expressed by the Munsif-Magistrate and companyfirmed the order of acquittal.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Munsif-Magistrate and confirmed acquittal

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court agreed with the view expressed by the Munsif-Magistrate and companyfirmed the order of acquittal. The State of Rajasthan preferred the present appeal questioning the companyrectness of the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan preferred present appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: the Munsif-Magistrate found that the search was made by the Deputy Superintendent without recording the reasons as he should under s. 165 of the Criminal Procedure Code

facts.text: Supreme Court holds search under r. 201 Central Excise Rules must follow s. 165 CrPC including recording reasons

facts.text: Search made by Deputy Superintendent was illegal for contravention of s. 165 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned, we hold that the search made by the Deputy Superintendent in the present case in companytravention of the provisions of s. 165 of the Code was illegal.

issues.text: Whether the Central Excise and Salt Act, Rules and CrPC distinguish between power to search and manner thereof such that for a search by excise officer to gather information for levy of duty (not for prosecution), the general mode under s.103 CrPC applies rather than s.165 CrPC for police investigation of offence?

anchor.surface_text: 1  The Central Excise and Salt Act  1 of 1944   hereinafter called the Act  and the Rules framed thereunder  hereinafter called the Rules  and the Criminal Procedure Code  hereinafter called the Code , maintain a distinction between the power to make a search and the manner of making it, and companylate a specified power with a particular procedure. As the Deputy Superintendent of the Central Excise,

issues.text: Assuming s.165 CrPC applies to the excise search, whether recording of reasons is jurisdictional (power conferred thereby) such that excise officer with power under r.201 need only follow procedural parts, not recording?

anchor.surface_text: 2  Assuming that s. 165 of the Code applies, the said section confers a power or jurisdiction on a police officer to make a search and prescribes the procedure to be followed in making the search. The recording of the reasons relates to jurisdiction and therefore the excise officer, who has already derived his power to make the search under r. 201 of the Central Excise Rules, need only follow the procedural part of s. 165 of the Code.

issues.text: Whether the search by the Deputy Superintendent under r.201 Central Excise Rules without recording reasons as required under s.165 CrPC was illegal, rendering the respondent's obstruction thereto not an offence under s.353 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: in accordance with s. 165 of the Criminal Procedure Code and remanded the case for fresh enquiry. arguments.claim: The Central Excise and Salt Act, Rules and CrPC maintain a distinction between power to search and manner of making it; since the search was to gather information for excise duty not for prosecution/investigation of offence, s.103 CrPC (general searches) applies, not s.165 CrPC (police investigation searches)
